title: Catfish spotted swimming on flooded streets in Florida during Hurricane Debby
message:
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. – Catfish were spotted swimming along residential Florida driveways and yards ahead of Debby’s landfall as a Category 1 hurricane.
Joanna Mack and her husband were amazed to see two catfish swimming in the road outside their Pinellas Park home on Sunday.
4 Catfish were spotted in flooded streets in Florida during Hurricane Debby.
StoryfulThe National Hurricane Center upgraded Debby to a Category 1 hurricane on Sunday evening.
4 The forecast cone for Tropical Storm Debby.

title: Hurricanes dont stop at the coast – these mountain towns know how severe inland flood damage can be , and theyre preparing
message:
A U.S. map of hurricane storm tracks since 1851 shows that the storms and their remnants often travel far inland.
Green is tropical storm strength, and blue and gray are weaker but can still be damaging.
NOAA Climate.govIn 1955, Connie, followed closely by Diane, produced some of the worst inland river flooding in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and Massachusetts.
Vermont was caught off guard by Tropical Storm Irene in 2011, which swept away hundreds of homes.
In 1998, Tropical Storm Charley traveled nearly 200 miles up the Rio Grande Valley, quickly flooding the dry Texas landscape, with devastating consequences.

title: Debby continues its assault on the Southeast
message:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WSMV) - Debby made landfall as a hurricane, but even now as a tropical storm, it continues wreaking havoc on the Southeast.
Rainfall amounts are off the charts already in the coastal Southeast with even more rain to come from Tropical Storm Debby.
Nearly an inch of rain is estimated to have fallen in much of the southeast, especially in coastal areas of FL, GA, SC, and NC.
Some of the hardest hit areas have been coast Georgia and coastal South Carolina.
In the Charleston, South Carolina area, there were three suspected tornadoes overnight Monday and into early Tuesday.

title: ENC residents stock up on essentials ahead of Tropical Storm Debby
message:
GREENVILLE, N.C. (WITN) - Eastern Carolina is starting to feel the effects of Tropical Storm Debby tonight.
Greenville residents said they’re stocking up on milk, eggs and bottled water ahead of Debby’s impacts in the east this week.
Elisa Johnson lived in Florida before moving to Eastern Carolina, so she is no stranger to tropical storms.
She’s seen the good, bad and ugly of hurricane season, but she’s hoping Debby won’t cause a ton of damage.
Other residents said they bought bread and canned goods in case their power or water goes out from the storm.

title: Slow - moving Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains and flooding to southeastern US
message:
Slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby bringing torrential rains and flooding to southeastern USA man walks through storm surge on the flooded road into Horseshoe Beach, Fla., Monday morning, Aug. 5, 2024.
The storm was forecast to move relatively slowly across some of America's most historic Southern cities, including Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.
The National Hurricane Center has forecast up to 25 inches (64 centimeters) of rain in some areas.
The storm's center was 10 miles (15 kilometers) southeast of Savannah, the hurricane center said in its 2 p.m. advisory Tuesday.
North Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.

title: Rainfall totals nearing five inches over last 48 hours in parts of Grand Strand Pee Dee , National Weather Service says
message:
Rainfall totals nearing five inches over last 48 hours in parts of Grand Strand Pee Dee, National Weather Service saysHORRY COUNTY, S.C. (WBTW) — Tropical Storm Debby has already dropped nearly five inches of rain in parts of the Grand Strand since Sunday as the system is expected to hover for most of the week bringing even more precipitation.
As of 7 p.m. Tuesday, Spring Gully in Georgetown picked up 4.62 inches of rain, while North Myrtle beach and sections of Conway eclipsed three inches, according to National Weather Service figures.
Other notable amounts included:3.5 inches north of Bucksport2.73 inches in Briarcliffe Acres2.7 inches in Longs2.56 inches in DeBordieu2.37 inches in central Horry County1.8 inches in Aynor1.73 inches in Socastee1.54 inches in Loris1.48 inches at the Waccamaw RiverDebby’s strongest impacts are expected over the coming days, with forecasters projecting up to 30 inches of rain possible in some areas.
Henry McMaster said officials are preparing for heavy flooding not only in areas known for it, but parts of the state that typically stay dry.
“We’re preparing for that kind of heavy rainfall, and the kind of danger that comes with that kind of flooding,” he said.

title: Debby douses Southeast with rain as it moves along Atlantic coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby doused coastal cities in Georgia and South Carolina, stirred up tornadoes and flooded streets with waist-high floodwaters Tuesday.
Heavy rain is expected to move north into parts of South Carolina and North Carolina.
Debby was projected to travel through cities, including Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina, as the National Hurricane Center is predicting roughly 25 inches of rain in some areas.
Tornadoes knocked down trees and damaged a few homes on Kiawah Island and Edisto Island between Savannah and Charleston, South Carolina.
FILE-In this aerial view, a street is flooded by Tropical Storm Debby on August 6, 2024 in Savannah, Georgia.

title: FIRST ALERT WEATHER DAY : More heavy rain , flash flooding expected on Wednesday
message:
MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (WMBF) - Debby continues to drift around to our south, ushering in more rounds of flooding rain on Wednesday.
This forecast track will keep the rounds of heavy rain going on Wednesday, with gustier winds arriving on Thursday.
While not continuous, rain bands will usher in rounds of flooding rain through Thursday.
2-5 inches of rain fell earlier Tuesday, and additional heavy rain will lead to rapid runoff and additional flood concerns.
Another 5" - 10" of rain is expected through Thursday (WMBF)RIVER FLOODINGThe heavy rain is expected to swell local rivers through the weekend.

title: New Update - Debby Most Intense Rainfall Still Ahead : Here When Storm Will Affect Northeast
message:
Landfall was around 7 a.m. Monday, Aug. 5 about 70 miles southeast of Tallahassee, the National Hurricane Center said.
It was downgraded to a tropical storm shortly thereafter as it hit Florida's Gulf Coast with flooding rain, damaging winds, and storm surge.
The slow-moving system is expected to affect the Northeast later this week, especially southern New England and potentially parts of Long Island.
In the first image above, areas that will experience some impacts are marked in yellow.
Debby was upgraded from a tropical storm to a hurricane at about 11 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 4.

message:
South Carolina Gov.
The storm was forecast to slowly move out to sea, then creep back onshore over South Carolina on Thursday morning.
Green Pond in rural Colleton County, South Carolina, reported the most rain so far, just over 14 inches (36 centimeters).
President Joe Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

title: Tropical Storm Debby drenches Southeast with rain , high water as it drifts along the Atlantic coast
message:
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move north into parts of South Carolina and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said Debby hasn’t yet been as bad as feared, but he warned residents the slow-moving storm was far from over.
It will be a nervous few days for northern South Carolina and southern North Carolina where forecasters warned up to 15 inches of rain could fall.
President Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina.
The hurricane center predicts the system could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington, D.C., area by Saturday.

title: 19 - year - old killed after tree falls through home in high winds , rain from Tropical Storm Debby
message:
MOULTRIE, Ga. (WALB/Gray News) - Tropical Storm Debby continues to cause massive flooding and damage across the Eastern Seaboard after slamming into Florida on Monday.
The storm has brought with it torrential rain and high winds that have contributed to several deaths.
Colquitt County Coroner C. Verlyn Brock in Georgia reported the county’s first death due to the storm on Monday.
According to Castleberry, Tropical Storm Debby also damaged other roofs and powerlines in the Moultrie area.
theThe National Hurricane Center said record-setting rain is expected in certain parts of the country as the storm continues to move up the East Coast.

title: Tropical Storm Debby slow movement brings over a foot of rain to some locations
message:
Tropical Storm Debby’s slow movement brings over a foot of rain to some locationsINDIANAPOLIS (WISH) — Debby made landfall as a hurricane Monday morning as a Category 1 storm with maximum winds of 80 mph.
The rainfall from the system is the major impact of the storm’s slow movement up the coast.
Flooding will continue in eastern Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina as Debby is still dropping rain in these locations.
It is not out of the question that spots in the Carolinas make a run at 30 inches of rain once this storm system is over.
Rainfall estimates of what has fallen as of 4:30 p.m. EDT, Aug. 6, 2024Additional rainfall possibleFuture Track of Tropical Storm DebbyAs of 5 p.m. EDT, Debby is a tropical storm with maximum winds of 40 mph.

title: Tropical Storm Debby soaks US southeast
message:
More than 20cm of rain have already fallen on Savannah and Valdosta, Georgia, the National Weather Service said.
Charleston and Hilton Head, South Carolina, have received between 25 to 30cm of rain so far, the weather service said, with more on the way.

title: Tropical Storm Debby drenches Southeast as it drifts along Atlantic coast
message:
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move north into parts of South Carolina and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said Debby hasn't yet been as bad as feared, but he warned residents that the slow-moving storm was far from over.
North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency Monday, and Virginia Governor Glenn Youngkin declared the same for his state on Tuesday.
Green Pond in rural Colleton County, South Carolina, reported the most rain so far from Debby with just over 36 centimeters (14 inches).
President Joe Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.

title: Shop owners in Swansboro prep amid flooding fears , reflect on past storm struggles
message:
Swansboro natives are remembering Hurricane Florence and are thankful that things are not expected to be as bad as they were then.
In Swansboro, the rain was coming down pretty hard Tuesday afternoon.
People in Swansboro are nervous about the upcoming storm and doing the best they can to prepare for Debby.
I lost my very first building to Hurricane Florence and it's been a job to recover from that.
Though some locals are worried about the upcoming rain, many are not as concerned due to the damage that came with Hurricane Florence a few years ago.

title: Victoria struck by 4 . 1 magnitude earthquake
message: While Australia didn't have an active tectonic plate boundary like in New Guinea or New Zealand, stress from other boundaries slowly built up to the interior of the plate, eventually causing faults to fail, Prof Cummins said.

title: The Latest : Tropical Storm Debby churns off the US Southeast
message: The Latest: Tropical Storm Debby churns off the US SoutheastThe mayor of Charleston, South Carolina, says the peninsula that makes up much of the city's historic downtown will remain closed Tuesday as Tropical Storm Debby spins nearby

title: From strangers to buddies , these wildfire survivors are back together on 1 - year anniversary
message:
Approaching the year anniversary of the Maui wildfire, they were reunited in Kapalua.
Strangers turned buddies, brought together during the Lahaina fire storm.
Fernandez turned around and drove back down.
That’s when he saw Brunel clinging to a tree.
“I love him and consider him a friend — friend with a capital F — for the rest of my life,” Brunel said.
